thread.title: Mysterious six-metre long hairy 'sea monster' washes up on beach - but what is it? - Mirror Online
thread.title_full: Mysterious six-metre long hairy 'sea monster' washes up on beach - but what is it? - Mirror Online

author: Patrick Lion
title: Mysterious six-metre long hairy 'sea monster' washes up on beach - but what is it? - Mirror Online
text:
The "hairy" blob found on a beach in Cagdainao, Dinagat Islands, in the Philippines, this week Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A "hairy" sea creature has washed up on the shore of an island in the Pacific Ocean - triggering debate over what it is. 
Speculation has identified the six-metre long creature, often referred to as a "globster", as different types of whale , a dugong, a giant fish or herbivorous sea cow. 
It's striking feature is the "hair" covering its body but one expert has reportedly insisted this is probably muscle fibres being exposed by decay. 
However, this decay was making it difficult for experts to identify what type of creature it was. One man posted this photo on Twitter referring to the creature as a dugong 
The creature was discovered on a beach in Cagdainao, Dinagat Islands, in the Philippines. 
There is speculation it may have died during a recent earthquake in the region, following reports of other sea life washing up on the shores. 
Orca head of science and conservation Lucy Babey told the BBC it was definitely the carcass of a dead animal she believed was a whale. Read More Manatees (Photo: Getty) 
"It's definitely a very decomposed sea creature in the later stages of decomposition," she told the broadcaster. 
"That would suggest that it was probably a whale." 
"They have numerous whale species in the Philippines such as the blue whale, fin whales and humpback whales as well as smaller whales such as minke whales. 
"But they also have manatees out there, so it could be a manatee. (Photo: Getty)
